titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: I received a Letter from George H. Derby, brevet second Lieutenant of the Ordnance, whose admission as a Cadet at the West Point Academy, I had obtained by the favour of John Bell, Secretary of War in 1842, and who has recently graduated 7th. of his class, soliciting my influence to obtain for him a transfer from the Ordnance to the Corps of Topographical engineers I called this morning at the Pension Office with some additional papers in support of the claim of Eleanor Shepherd, which I left with the Commissioner. Then on Coll. J. J. Abert and was referred by him to Genl Scott, who after some pourparler sent for Coll. Talcott and finally promised to me that Lieutt. George H. Derby should be transferred to the corps of Topographical engineers— In the house a Resolution was adopted to close debate on the Warehousing bill at Noon this day— The debate itself was a mockery— The engrossment of the bill was carried 117 to 52— Grinnell and Winthrop voting for it— Ashmun, Hudson— D. P. King, Rockwell, and Thompson with me voting against it— Abbott did not vote— It is the golden key to f. . . on the revenue—The Bill was passed and returned without amendment to the Senate— Private bills from the Senate were then taken up, 4 of which were passed— A bill for the relief of Harriette Ward, widow of a Lieutenant in the Navy produced a perfect anarchy of two hours in the house and then was passed without further struggle— Army appropriation Bill— Disagreements between the two houses— Conference could not agree— Senate adhere— Ashmun move to recede lost 67 to 69— Dromgoole excused from voting— House insist and ask a second conference— Amendments of Senate to the subtreasury bill referred to the Committee of Ways and Means—Adjourned—

In the Hall of the House of Representatives, the Chaplain of the House preached his last Sermon for the Session from Ecclesiasts 9.10 [“]Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do it with thy might: for there is no work, nor device, nor knowledge nor wisdom in the grave whither thou goest” Mr Milburn is said to be blind, but he has no appearance of it at the Clerks table whence he speaks—and he walks without a guide— He was brought here from what is called the far West and among the worshipers of the wilds passes for eloquent— His discourses consist of commonplace Calvinism without intolerance or dogmatism— Quiet, inoffensive, pious, moral, but to my judgment so far from eloquent that from my constant attendance upon his ministrations on the Sabbath through this long Session, there is not a thought which I have heard from him remaining in my Memory. There was this morning a dedication of a new Baptist Church in E Street East of the Post-Office to which I received a printed circular invitation from the Trustees, but which I did not attend— There was no service this afternoon at St. John’s church—and I believe none at the second Presbyterian which is now without a Pastor The change from the Summer to the autumnal atmosphere commenced this day a full fortnight earlier than usual—and with the change a corresponding one is promised of my health— I read a few pages of the philosophy of the plan of Salvation—Calvinism in extremis— But I am yet under the influence of indolence— Is it strenua inertia?

I received this morning from the adjutant General Roger Jones a copy of an order from the War Department transferring Brevet 2d. Lieutenant George H. Derby from the Ordnance Department to the Corps of Topographical Engineers. Letter of 1. Augt. from my Son— Offer for my house in Hancock Street— H.R.U.S. Washington Hunt New-York moved to suspend the rules for an amendment of the Constitution to make the President ineligible for a second term and to prohibit the appointment of Members of Congress to Office— Suspension of Rules and even yeas and nays refused Dodge of Iowa moved a gratuity from the contingent fund to the officers, clerks, messengers, pages and labourers, like that bestowed by the Senate on theirs— Lost 75 to 77— Garrett Davis moved to suspend the rules for a Committee of enquiry whether the Treasury Department is issuing paper money.— Suspension of the Rules refused. Martin of Wisconsin moved a distribution of books to the members of this Congress which have been furnished to the members of the last— Dromgoole moved to lay the Resolution on the table—lost—69 to 96. Distribution carried 89 to 73. Ligon moved to close debate on the French spoliation Bill at 2. P.M this day— Motion laid on the table— Veto of the River and Harbour Bill received from P.U.S. Moderate debate thereon till the adjournment at 4.— Visit from Elliot C. Cowdin of Boston, with an invitation on behalf of the Boston Mercantile Library association to deliver a Lecture before them next October, which I promised conditionally—my health permitting. Subject our Country. Evening visits from Theodore Moody. Archibald Campbell and his brother from Albany.

I received a Letter from J. B. Howard, of 31. July Walpole, Massachusetts, with a petition from him and 4 others with an alternative of separation by Mason and Dickson’s line— And a Letter from Mr Washington Hunt, requesting an Autograph for Mrs. Hunt. H.R.U.S. The Veto Message was resumed— John Wentworth had moved an amendment to Dromgoole’s motion to print the Veto Message, to print with it parts of the President’s annual message, to shew his inconsistency.— After some debate the previous question was carried on the Vetoed Bill, the vote on which was 95 to 93. a majority but not two thirds so that the bill was lost.— French spoliation Bill Hamlin moved to close the debate in one hour. Cobb moved to lay the bill on the table lost 68 to 113— Thurman, M’Clelland, Cobb occupied the whole hour against the bill and when the time for voting came a swarm of amendments to defeat the bill followed, all rejected.— It was reported without amendment, under the previous question, passed for engrossment 93 to 88—passed for enactment 94 to 87—and reconsideration refused 79 to 95. Relief from long and deep agitation— I went this Evening to the astronomical Observatory to take a glance at the moon near full (7th. 1.10. A.M.) through. the Frauenhofer Refractor. Lieutt. Maury was not there— Mr Hubbard was— I saw the Moon, Antares and Saturn— Three Gentlemen, one of whom was a member of Congress with three Ladies were also there. I came home about 10 in the Evening. The Steamer Hibernia arrived yesterday morning at Boston— Left Liverpool 19. July Whig ministry in England— Lord John Russell, premier— Oregon Treaty ratified.

I received a Letter from Ben P. Green a son of Duff Green soliciting my aid to carry through the house an item of appropriation for compensation as Chargé d’Affaires U.S. at Mexico.— And a Letter from George Jay 18 July Pentonville. H.R.U.S. Among the Bills and Amendments from the Senate were Amendments to Amendments of the house upon the Senate Bill to reduce and graduate the price of public Lands to actual settlers— Brodhead moved to lay the Bill on the table— M’Clernand moved a call of the House—refused 56. to 113. and the bill was laid on the table 184 to 59. This was retaliation for the veto upon the river and harbour Bill—but nothing more— It will not save the public lands—but abandon to ruin the Northern and Eastern harbours— I reached the house immediately after the vote was taken, and did not vote upon it—the Amendments of the Senate to the Subtreasury, were after a feeble struggle all concurred in, and after the rejection of a motion by George Ashmun to lay the Bill on the table it was finally passed. 101 to 77— A bill from the Senate to remit duties on the importation of Rail road iron was at the motion of Roberts of Missouri laid on the table 131 to 41. M’Kay moved several resolutions respecting the distribution of books to members Navy Appropriation Bill— Committee rose for lack of Quorum— Adjourned by yeas and nays. 74 to 63. Conversation with Elisha Whittlesey about judge John M’Lean— Evening visits from Mr and Mrs Francis B. Stockton and from Mrs Talbot and her daughter Mary— I went to Mr Frye’s with a Letter from J. M. Poe Baltimore proposing to rent the Columbia Mills for a Cotton factory—

Fahrenheit 86. at Sunrise— Blazing Sun all day long— Flat calm day and Night: The very calenture of the Summer. Its effects upon me, body and mind I cannot describe— I received a note from Miss Milligan, with the present of a miniature painted by her of my dear wife; Also a Letter from Thomas J Smith Hendrick’s Mill, Russell Co. Virginia—with a Newspaper the Virginian 11. July 1846. published at Abingdon— Also from M’Lane the Serjeant at arms, my account of compensation for the Session At the house the Report of the Committee of Conference upon the bill for the relief of Richard Elliott was received and adopted and the bill passed That of the second Committee of conference on the army appropriation bill was also adopted and the bill passed— The Civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill and the West Point Academy Bill were before the house upon amendments between the two houses. A joint Resolution to pay for Militia called out by General Gaines with out law, passed as it came from the Senate, rejecting an addition proposed by Jacob Thompson— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Linn Boyd chairman on the Bill reported by Hopkins for the establishment of 185 new Post routes— Bill to establish a Government in the territory of Oregon—debate on the boundary— None in the bill— Anti Slavery clause carried. Grant to Mary widow of Captain Gray failed 73 to 77 The bill passed— Comee. of the whole Union. Tibbatts chairman Peruvian indemnity bill debated— Committee discharged and bill passed— I spoke 10 minutes on the bill to establish the Government of the Oregon Territory— Mrs. Albion K. Parris and her daughter Julia spent part of this Evening with us.

I received a Letter from my old friend John Davis, late, and many years judge of U.S. District Court Massachusetts— It is all in his own handwriting and almost illegible—but encloses 8 lines of verse full of calm, philosophical and pious resignation under the decays of nature in the last stage of human life— My sympathies with him are more than fraternal. At the House the report of the second conference on the army appropriation Bill was accepted and the bill passed— The civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill was labouring with amendments pile upon pile between the two houses— While discussing these Amendments the house took a recess from 3 to 5 P.M. and at the invitation of Mr Grinnell, I went and dined with him and his fellow lodgers at Mrs Whitwells— Mrs Grinnell Mrs Davis and all the Ladies of the party are gone— There was a light shower with distant thunder while we were at dinner. On returning to the house at 5 O’Clock; I found the Speaker had resumed the Chair, but there was no Quorum— I moved a call of the House which was carried— At the first roll call 109 and at the second 140, when further proceedings were suspended The civil and diplomatic appropriation bill was resumed in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Hopkins chairman and debated till 10 at night when the Committee rose—the previous Question was moved—a motion by Dromgoole to adjourn was lost and the same motion immediately after by Hamlin was carried— I went and took up the Ladies, at the lodgings of Mr and Mrs Stockton where they had spent the Evening.

Morning call from Lund Washington senior with an engraved portrait of General George Washington which he seemed to think a novelty, and wished a certificate from me of it as a likeness— It was the engraving of Trumbull’s Trenton portrait of which I told him I possessed a copy purchased at the Hague in May 1795. but I could not certify it as a strong likeness. C. P. Montgomery and George Green were also here. H.R.U.S— The usual intercourse of conferences upon disagreeing votes between the two houses upon several bills occupied great part of the day, but the event, was a Message, asking an appropriation of two millions of dollars, to negotiate a Peace with Mexico— Referred on Dromgoole’s motion to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Moses Norris of New-Hampshire Chairman— M’Kay introduced a Bill. Close debate— Recess from 3 to 5— Limitation of the debate— Whig vacillation— Queer speeches on all sides mixed motives and impulses David Wilmot’s proviso— M’Kay at my suggestion modified his proposed bill. Jos R. Ingersoll’s substitute. David Wilmot’s proviso again— M’Kay’s modified Bill with Wilmot’s proviso reported to the house 77 to 59.— Tibbatts moved to lay it on the table lost 78 to 94— Wick—Barringer Grider Bill engrossed 85 to 73— PassedRefusal to reconsider 70 to 83— M’Kay voted against the Bill and all the South—Whig or Democrat— Massachusetts Adams Hudson, Rockwell, Thompson Winthrop vote for the bill— Abbot, Ashmun, Grinnell, D. P. King did not vote— M’Kay move to suspend 16th. joint rule to send the bill to the to the Senate—Carried. Adjourned ten minutes before 11— French spoliation bill vetoed When I came home I found Archibald Campbell, and Isaac Hull Adams here. Proclamation of the Oregon Treaty—

There was no preaching at the Capitol— I attended the morning service at St John’s church where Mr Pyne read the prayers for the ninth Sunday after Trinity, and preached from John 3.18 [“]He that believeth on him is not condemned: but he that believeth not is condemned already, because he hath not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God.” The discourse was upon Faith and disclosed to my mind no new idea.— On Saturday 5. August 1809—I sailed from Charlestown for St. Petersbourg with my wife, and child Charles F. and others— The next day 6. August 1809 was the ninth Sunday after Trinity and I read to my wife on board ship the service of that day, with an impression which is not effaced— And all the while we were in Europe we continued the practice— Mr Pyne’s discourse was upon saving Faith—a perplexing subject— At 4 this afternoon I attended at the second Presbyterian church, where the Revd. Mr Patten of the Columbian College, preached from Philippians 4.6 [“]Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication, with thanksgiving, let your requests be made known unto God.”— The Sermon was upon prayer—supplication with thanksgiving— Mr Patten made no remarks upon the injunction to be careful for nothing—which deserves and perhaps requires a qualifying commentary— The spirit of the gospel is frequently monitory against the excess of worldly cares but it is only the excess that is forbidden, to which the more selfish morality of Solomon might lead— To be careful for nothing is a hyperbole a figure of speech often used by Jesus— We had evening visits from Mr Moseley to take leave from Mr M’Rea and Lieutenant Thom.
Close of 1 Session 28. Congress.

The House met at 8 O’Clock A.M. The adjournment was fixed at Noon for the convenience of members many of whom departed in the Railway Cars for Baltimore at that hour— The day like all the last days of a Session of Congress was a Chaos of confusion— It began by a Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Howell Cobb chairman upon an amendment of the Senate to the Navy appropriation Bill— There was a large majority to disagree to the Senates amendment but no quorum voting— Cobb declared the disagreement carried though Garrett Davis had called for a division and remonstrated that there was no quorum. Cobb rode rough shod over Garrett Davis, and was sustained in his false report, by the Speaker John W Davis who in mockery of Garrett Davis’s remonstrance said he could receive nothing as done in Committee but the Report of the Chairman— He put the question of concurring with the amendment of the Senate which was rejected 84 to 48— The Bill afterwards passed, by a report from a Committee of Conference, so did the civil and diplomatic appropriation bill— A joint Committee was appointed to inform P.U.S. that the two houses would adjourn at Noon but they made no report— Sims of S.C. and W. W. Campbell of New York moved to take up the bill for the relief of Elizabeth Hamilton—but failed— As the hand of the Clock was on the line of 12. the Speaker declared the house adjourned to the first Monday in December. At that moment John Davis was prosing in the Senate about, the two Million Peace bill with David Wilmot’s anti-slavery for proviso—which thereby fell through G. Ashmun had a letter from Captain Geisinger. Kavasales was here— My Ladies spent the Evening at Mrs Talbot’s— I joined them there and met there Mrs Newman and Mrs Thornton— Walk home— Mr Larned was also there.

Sommerauer is a petitioner to Congress for a pension—for services and sufferings in the last War— A bill for his relief passed the house at the late Session but slumped in the Senate and he now comes as a mendicant— Mrs Royalls Sally came upon the same errand— I called at the Department of State and claimed my copy of the 6th. Volume of the American Archives 4th. series, which Mr Markoe promised to send me to my house— We had some talk about the Smithsonian bequest act—just passed— At the National Intelligencer Office I saw Mr Gales—directed the paper to be sent to me after next Thursday at Quincy, and enquired if he had Yancey’s address to his Constituents on resigning his seat in Congress. He had not, but promised to publish it— At the Hall of the house of Representatives I withdrew from my table draw the remnant of my papers which I had left there yesterday; and made enquiries without success for the Peaslee petition and papers— In the Evening we had numerous visitors and music— Various singing with accompaniment of the Piano— Miss Lagniel and Mary Louisa Schroeder Campbell and I. H. Adams— At dinner I felt a hoarseness and sore throat coming upon me which increased all the Evening till it went with me to bed— My ailments frequently change their seats but allow me no respite—

5.30. Restless Night— My sore throat turns to my old catarrhal cough— Tussis senilis. Kavasales came almost despairing of his prospect. I called at the Bank of the Metropolis, and settled my account there. deposited the Speaker check for 102.60 the balance of my pay for the Session and drawing my own check for 460.10—the balance to my credit in the bank 460.10— I went next to the Navy Department, where the Secretary Bancroft gave me an order Kavasales to proceed to Norfolk Va and report to Commodore Wilkinson for duty at the Navy yard— We had some conversation concerning the Letter of Captain Geisinger to Mr Ashmun— Commodore Morris came in while I was there. Next to the Pension Office— Nathaniel Chick has not been there since I went with him— Mr Bancroft spoke to me of my father’s papers, and particularly of the note from Samuel Adams to him respecting the answer to Hutchinson’s message— I sent a copy of Fremonts Report to J. Carpenter—Blissfield Lenawee County, Michigan— Isaac Hull Adams dined with us, and Mary dined at Mr. and Mrs Stockton’s The Ladies rode out this evening, and took tea at Mrs Seaton’s— She sent us a basket of very fine fruit—Pears, plums nectarines and peaches— We had several evening visitors; but I was so unwell with cough and headache, that I had retired to bed and did not see them— The preparations for departure, and the unrelenting heat of the dog-days aggravate my complaints— I finished reading the Book of Psalms in a course commenced of the Bible 1. December 1845

Mr Kavasales came again and I delivered to him the order from the Secretary of the Navy to proceed to Norfolk Va. and report himself to Commodore Wilkinson for duty at that station as Chaplain, which Mr Bancroft had put into my hands yesterday and for which Kavasales expressed himself warmly grateful— After the bustle of a Caravan departure with my wife, my son John’s widow Mary Catherine, and her daughter Mary Louisa at 5 this afternoon I repaired to the train of Railway Cars for Baltimore— They started at 1/2 past 5. and in two hours landed us at the Depot in Baltimore; whence a hack immediately conveyed us to Barnum’s Hotel, in Monument square. With us as attendants are Thomas Dumphy, Coachman and Margaret Dulany housemaid— Mrs El. Goods also came with us, going with her daughter Janeto visit her daughter Catherine married to Jacob Carr at Quincy— Dr Thomas came with us to Baltimore. Mrs Goods with her daughter Jane and Margaret Dulany proceeded by the Night Steamer to Philadelphia We passed the Evening at Barnum’s Hotel with more than usual relief from the canicular Sun and Nights of Washington where the average of Fahrenheit has for the last three weeks has been with the exception of 3 cold days 86.— I left the draft of the Treasurer of Pennsylvania Snowden on the Bank of Pennsylvania in favour of Nathaniel Chick with Lieutt. Thom who promised to deliver it to the Commissioner of Pensions tomorrow— I suppose Chick will apply there— It is more than 3 weeks since he last came to me and I have been expecting him every day since.

August. 14. Friday. IV:30— From Baltimore by Railway Cars to Philadelphia. J. Q. A. L. C. A. Mary Catherine Adams, Mary Louisa Adams with Thomas Dumphy— Hack to Jones’s Union Hotel— Dinner at Lady’s ordinary— Hack to the Steamer— Landed at Bristol Railway Cars to New-York— Met Captain John Tyler and his Son Robert— Revd. M’Milam— Talk about David, Solomon, Psalms and proverbs— Two German Harpers with a Clarinet made music for us— Astor house at 1/2 past 9. P.M. Met Thomas Frothingham on the wharf at Philadelphia— Thomas Dumphy hurt

15. Saturday— Break fast at 6.15— Leave the Astor house 6.45— Crossed the battery ferry at 7. Long-Island train of Railway cars start from Brookly at 7.15—95 miles to Greenport. Steamer Cinderella at 11. Mr and Mrs John A. Rockwell land and leave us at Norwich Rail way Cars to Boston land at United States Hotel— Tea. Meet Charles and his Son— Old Colony Rail-road at 1/4 past 7— Captain Dimmock: land at the depot at Quincy 7.45 Cheered at landing— Carriage home— Found Margaret here before 9. Mrs Charles greeted us here— [symbols]
16. Sunday. V— [symbols]
Revd. Dr Pierce of Brookline preached A.M from Deuteronomy 1.21. and P.M. from Acts 11.26 He dined with us— Unpacking— Fahrenheit 76— Light headed— Few Reflections— Began Proverbs 4. chapters a day—

1846. August 17. Monday. IV:30. Railway train Cars from Boston pass’d by my window 5.45 The train for Boston passed 6.45— Second train from Boston 7.45—Train from Plymouth 8.15— Johnson William B. from Utica—
18— 5.45— Railway train from Boston
6.45— Train from Plymouth to Boston
19. Wednesday 5 30. Railway train from Boston. Fahrenheit at Sunrise 50 at the door—66 in my chamber— Samuel Andrews Halibut and Mackerell— Train from Boston 7.45— Ambush William Edward Shaver.

div.p: Monday 24. IV.— Memm. Elias H. Derby—
Pension claims of James Ward—
Leavitt Joshua— Ink
Tuesday. 25. Boston— Earthquake—
Wednesday 26. Commencement— Red Ink.
Wild Cherry rum— Caleb B. Smith
Friday 28 Ladd Isaac of Meredith N.H.
Andrews Samuel— Halibut.
Saturday 29. Wild Jonathan of Braintree.
Monday 31. Paid John A. Green’s bill—$20 for 6 years Quincy Patriot and printing 100 copies of letter 4. July 1843—
Benedetto. Mendicant— Mary Ann Broderick

After a Night of calm repose, I rose at half past 4 this morning— Fahrenheit 86— We breakfasted at 8. and took the train of Railway cars which started at 9 A.M from Baltimore for Philadelphia— From Barnum’s hotel to the depot we went in a hack—then in the cars drawn by horses to the borders of the city, where the horses were dismissed: and the locomotive took their place— At 3. P.M we reached the out-skirts of Philadelphia where horses again took the place of the locomotive and landed us at the depot in market street— Thence we proceeded in a hack to Jonas’s Union Hotel in Chesnut street There we dined at the Lady’s ordinary and at half past 4 proceeded in a hack to Walnut Street wharf, and embarked in the Steamer which in an hour and a half landed us at Bristol— There we entered the train of cars, and passing through Trenton, Princeton, New Brunswick, Rahway, Elizabeth town and Newark, at 9 in the Evening, brought us to Jersey city safe— We crossed the ferry and taking a hack at the foot of Cortland Street at 9.45—reached the Astor house New-York. The transportation of this day from Baltimore to New York, was but a trivial incident now common to hundreds every day in the year and many days to thousands— I met on the way sundry fellow travellers with whom I had previous slightly remembered or forgotten acquaintance, the only remarkable one of which was the late Vice-President of the United States acting and self styled President of the United States, John Tyler, and his eldest son Robert Tyler— Civilities, very polite, but on my part cool passed between us. We had two German women with harps who played and sung popular songs accompanied by a male Clarion, and made delightful music and pleasant pastime—

New-York Saturday 15. August 1846.
Long-Island Greenport Norwich Worcester Boston Quincy.
div.p: V. I rose after a good nights rest at 5. Breakfasted at 6.25— Left the Astor house at 6.45. Crossed the battery ferry at 7. Took the Long Island train of Railway Cars from Brooklyn to Greenport 95 miles— Strangely barren strand all the way— Almost suffocated with dust embarked at 11. in the Steamer Cinderella In company with Mr and Mrs John A. Rockwell to Norwich their residence where they took leave of us— Cool rain from Norwich to Worcester— Then through Framingham Natick, Newton, Brighton to Boston where just before 6. P.M. we alighted at the United States Hotel immediately opposite the Railroad depot— Tea at the United State Hotel 2.50. At 1/4 past 7. The train of Cars of the Old Colony Railroad start— My Son was at the Depot to meet us, with his Son John Quincy— Both of them came out with us— As did Ex-President of Harvard University Josiah Quincy—and Captain Dimmock, a new resident of the town— The Stations where the Cars stop are at Savin Hill, Dorchester, Neponset and Quincy, each of which was announced by the conductor as the train reached the station— At the Depot at Quincy, there was a considerable assemblage of persons, to whom as we alighted Captain Dimmock announced with a loud voice the arrival home of John Quincy Adams Representative in Congress of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, whereupon there was a shout of three cheers. I apologized for not returning thanks in a speech, by the extinction of my voice— Our Carriage took us from the depot home, where we found my Son’s wife with her two sons Charles and Henry to receive us— Margaret the waiting maid had reached here before us, with Mrs Goods and her daughter Jane— John Kirk and his wife Elizabeth were also here and welcomed us home.

V.— Blessing praise and supplication to God on first rising from bed, on returning to my earthly home after an absence of nine months in the public service of my Country— Some discouragement of Soul follows the reflection that my aspirations to live in the memory of after ages as a benefactor of my country and of mankind, have not received the sanction of my maker— That the longing of my Soul through a long life to be numbered among the blessing bestowed by the Creator on the race of man is rejected, and after being trammeled and counteracted and disabled at every step of my progress my faculties are now declining from day to day into mere helpless impotence— Yet—at the will of my heavenly father why should I repine? Dr. John Pierce of Brookline preached at the Stone Temple this day by exchange with the Revd. Mr Lunt— His morning Sermon was from Deuteronomy 1.21. “Behold, the Lord thy God hath set the land before thee: go up, and possess it, as the Lord God of thy fathers hath said unto thee: fear not, neither be discouraged”— Dr Pierce was not thinking of Texas Mexico or Oregon, but of the Reports of Caleb and Joshua on returning from their exploration of the Land of Canaan, and of the heavenly land set before the Christian of the present age for his exploration and possession— All his applications to our times were spiritual— Dr Pierce dined with us— His afternoon discourse was from Acts 11.26. “And the disciples were called Christians first in Antioch.” This is an incident of historical fact very curious and interesting upon which the commentary might have been broader and deeper— Dr Pierce is of the salt of the earth— I commenced reading the book of Proverbs, and with a view to go through the remainder of the Bible by the close of the present year I propose to read henceforth 4 chapters every day—
Johnson William C
Quincy Josiah
Louisa Catherine Smith

I return to a quiet home, and to more than voluntary repose My health apparently firmer than at any time within the last fifteen months, but shaking more and more— I rose with coming dailight, but the sky was beclouded and I could get neither a first sight of Sirius nor of the rising Sun— The first thing that riveted my attention to the progress of civilization and Society in my native village, was the rush by my windows of the train of Railroad cars from Boston to Plymouth at 5.45—followed at 6.45 by the return train from Plymouth to Boston— I was all day thinking of a fixed steady specific occupation for the Season, and during the recess of Congress— I had an unexpected but only momentary morning visit from William Clarkson Johnson—from Utica, New-York where he says he has opened a lawyers office, and has as much business as he can do— My only excursion this day was about sunset when I walked up to my Son’s house, where I found them at tea— He went to bathe at Daniel Greenleaf’s landing, and his wife came to my house with me— My wife was quite ill, and almost the whole day confined to her bed— My Cousin Louisa Catherine Smith came out from Boston to spend the Summer with us. Evening visit from Ex President Josiah Quincy, who left an invitation from his Son, Mayor of Boston, to attend at the breaking ground of the Boston aqueduct at Long Pond next Thursday. Also an invitation from William Parker, Loring Norcross and James Whiting Sub committee of the city Council to the same celebration— I have received also an invitation from the President of Harvard University—Edward Everett to the Commencement on the 26th of this month— I have also a printed circular from William Mitchell President of the Trustees of the Nantucket Athenaeum 8th. mo. 12 1846. Soliciting contributions
IV:30. Change of Season— Fahrenheit at Sunrise 72
The expectation of leisure is a delusion—
Field Harvey
Johnson William C.
Lunt. Revd. William P

I received by mail a Letter from Oscar F. Keeler, Columbus Mississippi Augt. 6. 1846 with the fragments of a small glass vial, encased in a tin cylinder open at both ends and crushed out of shape; under a paper cover torn into pieces, which had been sealed, addressed Hon. John Q. Adams. Quincy; Mass— Glass with care— Postmarked Columbus Mi. Augt. 6—and under the words Glass with care Broken on its way from Columbus Miss to Montgomery Al— The Letter was rolled round the cylinder and as well as the paper cover is stained all over with the cordial that was in the vial and is of claret colour— But the Letter itself is in handsome hand writing and not at all defaced— Mr Keeler says the cordial is a vegetable compound of his own invention which has cured him of bleeding at the lungs and many others of asthma, bronchitis and sundry other complaints That he wishes to make money of it, and sends me a specimen to try, and write him my opinion of it.
Parkman Dr George
Mrs Edward Miller.
Miss Caroline Spooner.

The visitors of the morning are in the upper margin— Those of the afternoon this lower one— Harvey Field came to trade with me in land for which I shall refer him to my Son— William C. Johnson’s was a visit of reconsideration but was as short as that of yesterday—he would not stay to dine— Mr Lunts was a pastoral call— Dr Parkman came out in his gig and declined staying to tea— The Ladies of Mrs Miller’s family came for half an hour about Sunset— I found Charles and his family at tea— He and his wife walked down with me and spent the short evening with us. My wife continues unwell but was able to leave her chamber this Evening. Mrs John Adams and Mary Louis are also slightly indisposed.
IV:30. Fahrenheit at Sunrise 50 at the outer door.
66 in my chamber.
Andrews Samuel. with Halibut and Mackerel
Ambush William Edward, Shaver.

Mr and Mrs Minott of Neponset village— Mrs Josiah Quincy. with her two daughters Susan and Anna—and the two Miss Tufts’s Susan and Mercy from Weymouth— I took yesterday morning a Seidlitz powder which put me on the sick list for the day, which continues this day of transition from intense dog day heat to Autumnal frigidity.— I received a diploma in the Latin language, from the Societas Philozetiana of the College of the Western Reserve at Hudson in the Republic of Ohio, constituting me an honorary member of that Society in consideration of my Labours for Science and Letters, and of my friendly regard for such institutions. There is a large Seal appended to a blue silk ribband to this diploma which is signed by R. O. Hammond Scribe, but is not signed by the President of the Society— What the Societas Philozetiana is I am not advised, and do not understand the etymology of the word Philozetiana— Afternoon visit from P. P. F. Degrand who brought with him a budget of Newspapers— And Evening visits from our neighbours George W. Beale with his daughters Ann and Caroline andEmmons.— Who invited me to join a party for an excursion to Fall River and Newport by Railway and Steamer the day after tomorrow.— The British Steamerarrived this day at Boston— Sailed from Liverpool on the 4th. I walked up to my Sons house to see the setting Sun— They spent the Evening here— My Tussis senilis is troublesome, and the state of my mind gives me concern— My powers of thought scatter like the sparks end of an exploding skyrocket, and I feel as if I was awaking from a Nightmare dream
Fahrenheit at Sunrise 44.
He that justifieth the wicked, and he that condemneth the just, even they both are abomination to the Lord—
Proverbs 17.15

At eight O’Clock this morning I walked to the Quincy Station depot of the Old Colony Railroad where I met my Son— Took my Seat in the train of cars which then came in from South Braintree for Boston—25 Cents a ticket— Josiah Quincy, late President of Harvard University and his Son in Law Waterston were also in the cars— There are three Stations on the way— Neponset, just beyond the river— Dorchester, and Savin hill.— We reached the depot opposite the United States Hotel about 8.45— I walked with Mr Quincy and Mr Waterston to the house where Mr Waterston now resides inStreet. Here I passed an hour, chiefly inspecting an Album sent from England by Mr Coleman, the jewel of which was an original Letter from Edmund Burke to Sir William Hamilton at Naples. How the hour passed away I know not but a quarter before ten we walked to the depot of the Providence Railroad and found there Josiah Quincy junior Mayor, and the City Council of Boston with whom I went to Long Pond in Wayland to break ground for the construction of an Aqueduct to the City of Boston.— This ceremony of striking the spade foot into the ground was performed by the Mayor after a short address to him from Nathan Hale in the name of the Water Commissioners and a handsome speech of about ten minutes from him. He threw up the first shovel full of earth and then with a compliment invited me to strike the second which I did, and his father, 2d Passed Mayor of Boston struck the third. The spade had been made for the occasion, and had on its handle a silver inscription recording in advance the transaction— The company then repaired to a temporary shed or tabernacle at hand and set down to the number of about 300 to a temperance cold collation at which the Mayor presided— The company then returned in the cars to Boston just in time for me to take the Cars of the Old Colony Rail-road at 5 P.M. for Quincy. I alighted with my neighbour Emmons at the Bridge close to my remaining barn, and found my dear wife ill in bed— Charles came home in the 7 O’Clock train, and with his wife passed an hour of the Evening here— My health continues to promise [symbols] but my Memory, where is it?
Fahrenheit At Sunrise 54 with rain.
To do justice and judgment is more acceptable to the Lord than sacrifice. Proverbs 21.3.
Say not, I will do so to him as he hath done to me; I will render to the man according to his work 24.29.

The Newspapers from Boston contain full reports of the excursion yesterday of the Mayor and City council to Lake Cochetuitte otherwise called Long Pond to break ground for the construction of an Aqueduct to furnish Boston with water I drank a glass of the water on the border of the pond drawn from 20 feet beneath the surface fresh, cool, pure and soft as I ever tasted— I received a small duodecimo volume entitled Normans New Orleans and Environs containing a brief historical sketch of the Territory and the State of Louisiana from the earliest period to the present time, presenting a complete guide to all subjects of general interest in the Southern Metropolis, with a correct and improved plan of the city, pictorial illustrations of public buildings &c New-Orleans—published by B. M. Norman 1845— Degrand sent me out from Boston Wilmer and Smith’s Liverpool European Times of theinstt. containing a voluminous account of the visit of Prince Albert, the Queen of Great Britain and Ireland’s husband to Liverpool to lay the corner stone of a building to be called the Sailor’s home—not a hospital, but a boarding and lodging house for Seamen. I slipped through the hours from Breakfast at 8 till Noon in reading the narrative of this princely pageant— Degrand sent me also a map shewing the proposed Rail roads from Bridgewater to Old Colony Rail-road extrated from Bordens State Map— By T. J. Carter Engineer— Towards Sunset I walked out and visited Elizabeth C. Adams, and there met Mrs Stebbins her late Mothers Sister, Mrs Archibald Campbell with her two infant children Mrs Boyd another daughter of Mr Charles Harrod, and two Misses Morgan, sisters of his present wife— I called also to see Mrs Edward Miller at her house, but she was at her Son in Law George T. Bigelow’s— I walked home. My Son and his wife were here and hour of the Evening— My wife was still confined by sickness all this day to her bed.— The weather deterred me from joining in the excursion to Newport proposed by Mr Emmons and Mr Beale.
IV:15. Thick fog— Fahrenheit after Sunrise 58—
Boast not thyself of to morrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth. Proverbs 27.1.

Morning visitors— Dr Woodward The Holbrook’s are sons of Ichabod Holbrook a Lieutenant in the army of the revolutionary War—a pensioner under the act of 1818 till he died in 1823.— These are children claimants— The two Holbrooks Howard in the right of his wife Hannah a sister of the Holbrooks, and another sister named Elizabeth Kennedy—there was another sister named Relief Ryan, who died since last November when they applied to me before. See my diary for 25. Novr 1845 Vol. 19. p. 310— But I could tell them nothing of the state of their claim, not knowing where to look for their papers— I found however a letter from Nathl. Holbrook Randolph 6. Jany 1846 with enquiries concerning his claim in right of his father Nathaniel Holbrook who he says drew a pension from 1838 to June 1845 when he died— These are two distinct claims— Walter Wall was here with lobsters of which I took one for 8 cents.— My wife is convalescent and was up, part of this day— I began an attempt for a general assortment of my papers which are in a Chaos of confusion, and which I would fain put in order for my Executor— They embrace a period of seventy years, besides those of my father which extend to twenty years more. This movement must be systematic, continuous and persevering and includes the making of my last Will to supersede that of 14 October 1832—since which great changes have taken place both in my family and my property— Relying on divine Mercy for the continuance of my life and health I propose to postpone the making of my Will till next Summer, and to avail myself of this Season to set my house in order— Charles and his wife spent their Evening hour here
Fahrenheit at Sunrise 65. Sprinkling of rain
Seest thou a man that is hasty in his words? there is more hope of a fool than of him. Proverbs 29.20.
The 30th. chapter of Proverbs (the words of Agur, the Son of Jakeh) and the first 9 verses of the 31st. The words of king Lemuel, are not in the Septuagint.

At the stone Temple Mr Lunt preached this morning from 2. Peter 1.3. “According as his divine power hath given unto us all things that pertain unto life and godliness through the knowledge of him that hath called us to glory and virtue.” This was a good Sermon, upon the ordinary of Mr Lunt’s compositions, never coming down to the level of mediocrity; and never of faltering interest—but the discourse of this afternoon from John 14.16. “And I will pray the Father, and he shall give you, another Comforter, that he may abide with you forever. 17. Even the Spirit of Truth, whom the world cannot receive, because it seeth him not, neither knoweth him: but ye know him; for he dwelleth with you, and shall be in you”—was transcendant—and one of the remarkable discourses that I ever heard— He began with a brief historical narrative of the festival days celebrated by the Roman Catholic and English Episcopal churches—Christmas—Easter—Ascension day and Pentecost or Whitsunday when the Holy Ghost descended upon the Apostles— He did not approve of the annual celebration of these days, thinking it tended to superstition and preferring the simplicity of the puritan worship; but he described with glowing eloquence, the transformation of the Apostles in the fifty days between the day of the crucifixion and the day of the descent of the Holy Ghost—and his application of the subject to the duties of the Auditory was highly solemn and impressive— As I came out of meeting this afternoon Mrgave me a small pamphlet entitled Search the Scriptures, by Joseph Adams of the city of Roxbury aged 96. written in support of the Religion brought by our forefathers the pilgrims to Plymouth and against the Unitarian Doctrines—dotage. Charles and his wife here— My wife up this Evening.
IV. Fahrenheit 56. at Sunrise 5.16. Sunset. 6.
“To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven.” Ecclesiastes 3.1.

Baxter George Parish tax collector, with my parish-tax 25 May 1846— Poll 1:50. Real Estate 139. Personal Estate and income 100— Total 240.50.— They tax me for 69500 real and 50000 personal Estate— I took the bill ad referendum.

Ward James, a claimant for a revolutionary pension 86 years old says he was at the battle of White Plains and served in the Deane Frigate in 1780—born in New-York— Has no papers— Rufus Davis made affidavit to his service before Elias Hasket Derby Justice of Peace Boston. Lives in Derne Street.— To ascertain to-morrow, where E. H. Derby’s Office is, and if testimony for Ward can be obtained there— I took to the shop of Caleb Gill Stationer and book binder the manuscript 19th. volume of my Diary from 1. Jany 1845 to 10 August 1846. closing with the first Session of the 29th Congress to be bound— Mr Gill was not there, but his young man promised that the volume should be bound uniformly with the 18th. volume which was bound there— About half this volume is in hand writing other than mine—chiefly of my granddaughter Mary Louisa to whom I am greatly obliged for her assistance cheerfully rendered— I make very slow progress in the assortment of my papers, am yet unable to begin to write any thing other than this Diary— I walked up the hill and saw the Sun set clear at 6.16.15 by my Chronometer, and by the American Almanac 6: My Son and his wife spent the Evening hour here— I received by Mail a volume in small 8vo. An Exposition of the weakness and inefficiency of the Government of the United States of North-America— Printed for the author 1845— I have an indistinct remembrance of this book, and of some conversation with Joseph R. Ingersoll concerning it— There is some affectation of mystery in its publication, and in the transmission of this copy of it to me— Anonymous— Without name of place or of printer, and sent to me by mail from Boston—
Fahrenheit at Sunrise 50.— Earthquake— Shower bath.
Be not rash with thy mouth, and let not thine heart be hasty to utter anything before God; for God is in heaven and thou upon earth: therefore let thy words be few— Ecclesiastes 5.2.

Early Breakfast, and as the Temple Clock struck 8. I reached, walking the depot of the Old Colony Railroad behind French’s tavern Ticket to Boston 25 Cents— My Son, his wife and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa went also but not in company with me— They were bound on a joint party to Mr Gorham Brooks’s at Medford— We parted at the Depot in Boston— I walked to N. 222 Washington Street and was shaved by Cadmus—then to my Son’s Office 23. Court Street where as one of Ward Nicholas Boylston’s I executed and acknowledged beforeSpooner Justice of Peace a deed of part of Wachusett Hill— At the Office of Elias Haskett Derby Justice of Peace I made enquiry of the papers to support the Revolutionary Pension claim of James Ward. He said they had all been sent ten or twelve years ago to the Pension Office at Washington, and his own books had been burnt— At the Emancipator Office— Conversation with Joshua Leavitt— Call at Abbott Lawrence’s counting house, but he was not there— Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society at Noon— James Savage the President and 10 members constituted the Meeting— Call on R. C. Winthrop on C. Hughes at the United States Hotel— Saw Miss Hughes and Miss Patterson— Then at James H. Foster’s— He went with me to the depot— Railway Cars to Quincy. 32 minutes. Mrs Stebbins, Mrs Campbell, and Elizabeth C. Adams were here after dinner. Ex-Senator Haywood’s Address to the People of North-Carolina— Mary-Louisa returned by the train at 8. P.M with Mrs Charles from Medford.
Fahrenheit at Sunrise 55. Rain— Commencement.

Or ever the silver cord be loosed, or the golden bowl be broken, or the pitcher be broken at the fountain or the wheel broken at the cistern. 7. Then shall the dust return to the earth as it was; and the spirit shall return unto God, who gave it. 8 Vanity of vanities, saith the Preacher, all is vanity. Ecclesiastes 12.6.7.8—

I want an exposition and commentary upon this passage. I received yesterday from John G. Palfrey Secretary of the Commonwealth an invitation to attend at the Council chamber in Boston at 8 O’Clock this morning to accompany the Governor to Cambridge to the exercises of Commencement at Harvard University— Had the weather been fair or indifferent my purpose was to go— But on rising at 4. I found the rain which commenced last Evening still continued with a Northeast wind— At 7. Notwithstanding the rain I walked to the depot, but the train was gone 20 minutes before, and the next train went at 6 minutes past 8—too late for me. At 9 came the mail and brought a rattle from Christopher Hughes written yesterday morning at the United States Hotel—Boston— I spent the whole morning in examining the condition of my papers with the purpose of assorting them, and found them in confusion inexpressible— I have to devise even a principle of arrangement for them— I had received on the 17th. of July a Letter from Stephen P. Hill and Franklin Wilson Committee of the first Baptist Church of Baltimore inviting me to deliver a Lecture in the course of next winter before that Society— The disorder of my correspondence, is the unfailing test of my caducity— This Letter has remained on my file unanswered till this afternoon— I now of course decline the invitation, not knowing what a day may bring forth— I received a pamphlet copy of William H. Haywood Junr, Address to the People of North-Carolina under a cover directed by himself, but did not find time to read it— Charles and his wife spent an evening hour with us. My wife was able to leave her chamber but is yet much indisposed.
IV. Fahrenheit 56. at Sun rise 5— Cloudy.

“O my dove, that art in the clefts of the rock, in the secret places of the stairs, let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice; for sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely.[”] Song of Solomon 2:14.

I had a special invitation from Edward Everett President of Harvard University to attend the Boylston prize declamations at 10 this morning—and another from Charles Henry Warren, President of the Phi Beta Kappa Society to attend at their anniversary celebration and dinner. I went in the Carriage driven by Albert Putnam, and leaving my Son at his office 23. Court Street Boston proceeded to Cambridge and alighted at the President’s house— At 10 the judges of the Prize-declamations met and proceeded to the church— There were only 8 speakers of the graduated and Senior classes— No junior. The judges retired to the President’s study, assigned the two first prizes to Masters and Norton and the three second prizes to Hudson, Ropes andWe returned to the Church where on the Stage President Everett announced the successful competitors for the prizes— We then immediately joined the Φ.B.K procession already formed and repaired again to the Church where a splendid Oration of two hours was delivered by Charles Sumner, a graduate of 1830. and a short poem byAt 3. the Society went again in procession and dined in Harvard Hall. James M’Dowell of Virginia Isaac Edward Morse a graduate of 1829. now a member of Congress from Louisiana, Revd. Dr Freeman once of Cape Cod, now an episcopal clergyman in North-Carolina, and other strangers were present. At half past 6 I left the table—and returned in my Carriage alone through Boston, home to Quincy where I landed at 8 P.M, where I found John De Wint as a visitor.— My Son came in afterwards. He had been at the Oration and the dinner, but I did not see him— Mr Thomas Loring had been here this afternoon, proposing a fishing party at Cohasset—
Thick fog. Fahrenheit 60 at Sun rise
“Many waters cannot quench love, neither can the floods drown it: if a man would give all the substance of his house for love it would utterly be contemned”
Solomon’s Song 8.7—
Ladd Isaac of Meredith—New Hampshire—Mendicant
My progress in making an assortment of all my papers is rather backward than forwards— I propose to arrange them Chronologically and to divide them into periods

list.item: 1 From Childhood till 1801. my return from Berlin.
4. From 1829 yearly to the close near at hand—

div.p: I received last evening from the Revd. L. D. Dewey of New-York a Letter—intreating me to contribute my opinions on the Bible and the Sabbath, to be published with an account of the Sabbath convention for the district of Columbia held at Washington last December and at which I presided— Mr Dewey was present at that Convention and mentioned his intention to publish in a pamphlet at New-York an account of its proceedings together with a Treatise of Sir Matthew Hale and the opinions of other eminent laymen concerning the Bible and the observance of the Sabbath— He requested a copy of my address to that Convention which was very brief and extemporaneous— But a Reporter for the Baltimore Sun had asked of me a copy of it for publication in that paper. I wrote it out the next morning and gave it to the Reporter who kept it, but it was not published in the Sun, nor at all.— There is no other copy of it extant and it has now faded irrecoverably from my Memory— Mr Dewey has repeatedly reminded me of my promise, but all that I can now do will be to write something for his publication as a substitute for my Address to the Convention— Ruth Turner the Seamstress was here this day, and John De Wint departed for an excursion to Boston or Somerville— Charles and his wife were here this Evening.
IV. Fahrenheit 65 at Sunrise Cloud after rain.

“And it shall come to pass in the last days, that the mountain of the Lord’s house shall be established in the top of the mountains, and shall be exalted above the hills; and all nations shall flow unto it[”]—
Isaiah 2.2.

I have been watching every morning since I got home for a sight of the rising of Sirius the dogstar at his heliacal morning appearance, but there has not yet been an unclouded morning eastern sky on which he could shew his face. This morning gloomed with fog— I took a Letter for Baltimore to the Post-Office, and was told that the Southern mail went out at 6. P.M. Returning home I stop’d at my Sons house, and found him with his family at Breakfast— Wild Jonathan of Braintree, came for a pension claim of his mother Deborah Wild, widow of Jonathan Wild a pensioner of the revolutionary War who died in 1840. There came as afternoon visitors a young man namedJames a Welshman from Swansea, who said he had been about a year in this Country and expected to return next Summer to Wales— His only object in his visit was curiosity to see me, and his companion a young man residing in Boston had no other— Then came Naaman L. White of Braintree, who in behalf of sundry citizens of that town invited me to a Pic Nic party at Spring grove in South Braintree next Tuesday at 2. O’Clock P.M. for the benefit of the sufferers by the recent fire at Nantucket— I declined attending this party—though fully approving its object. Mr Benjamin V. French is to preside— Mr White had a further motive for calling on me— He charges Fisher Ames Kingsbury, Postmaster at Weymouth, with gross official misconduct in frequently annoying him with anonymous Letters written by him, and conveyed by the Post-Office, and for which he exacts the Postage— Mr White wishes to complain of this to the Postmaster General Cave Johnson and asked my advice how to proceed—which I gave him— Mary Louisa went to riding School at Boston— Charles and his wife here this Evening.
IV Fahrenheit 68 at Sunrise—
Wo unto them that call evil good, and good evil; that put darkness for light, and light for darkness; that put bitter for sweet and sweet for bitter!
Wo unto them that are wise in their own eyes, and prudent in their own sight.
Isaiah 5.20–21.
I saw Venus as morning Star about an hour risen, and the whole constellation of Orion with Procyon—but Sirius was covered with a dark cloud—

Life of Emanuel Swedenborg— Born at Stockholm 29. January 1688— Illuminated in 1745. Mr Lunt preached A.M. from Ezekiel. 2.9—“And when I looked, behold, on hand was sent unto me; and lo, a roll of a book was therein; 3.1— Moreover he said unto me, Son of man, eat that thou findest, eat this roll, and go speak unto the house of Israel. 2. So I opened my mouth, and he caused me to eat that roll.” The text of his afternoon discourse was John 4.48—“Then said Jesus unto him, Except ye see signs and wonders, ye will not believe”— The morning was of high Summer heat with clouds gathering for a thunder shower, which came on immediately after I returned home from Meeting— I found P. P. F. Degrand, at my house and afterwards visitors from Boston— Mr George Alexander Otis, with his daughter, now named Mrs. Meade, and her mother Mrs Hickman— They are now residents at Richmond Virginia, and he says they have the charge of a very extensive establishment for the education of females. and have 150 pupils under their care— Mr Otis spoke to me of his translation of Cicero’s Offices, and of D’Olivet’s french translation of the Dialogue de Natura Deorum which I had lent him and which he has returned— We had some conversation also about Socrates; and the Republic, the Laws and the Dialogues of Plato— These visits arrested the progress of my reading of the Life of Emanuel Swedenborg. Charles and his wife passed the Evening here— And Degrand returned late to Boston
IV.
Fahrenheit 62 at Sunrise 5 Shower bath.
For every battle of the warrior is with confused noise, and garments rolled in blood; but this shall be with burning, and fuel of fire Isaiah 9.5.

This verse immediately precedes the passage understood to announce the advent of the Saviour— For, unto us a child is born, unto us a Son is given: and the Government shall be upon his shoulder; and his name shall be called Wonderful, Counsellor, the mighty God, the everlasting Father, the Prince of Peace— 7. Of the increase of his government and peace there shall be no end, upon the throne of David and upon his kingdom to order it and to establish it with judgment and with justice, from henceforth—even forever— The zeal of the Lord of hosts will perform this. In the Septuagint there is neither wonderful, nor mighty God, nor everlasting Father, nor Prince of Peace— The thought as expressed by Charles Thomson in his translation of the Septuagint has not a trace of the prophesy contained in this passage—and the translation by Lowth is totally different from both— The Summer heat still disqualifies me for the labour of assorting my papers and for reading with any settled purpose. My only visitor besides an Italian vagabond Mendicant named Benedetto was Mr Thomas Greenleaf my neighbour—80 years of age. After the excursion to see the rising Sun, I kept my chamber till between 5 and 6 P.M. when I took to the Post Office, my answer to the Letter from Mr Charles Sumner—a young man of whom I earnestly hope that he will contribute largely to redeem the Spirit of the free people of this Union from the dastardly servility to the Slave-monger oligarchy into which they have insensibly and almost unconsciously fallen— Returning home I stop’d at the new Eastern porch of my Son’s house, but neither he nor his wife was at home, but they spent the hour from 8 to 9 of the Evening with us.
